original_data.question: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department for evaluation of hemoptysis. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral focal pulmonary consolidation. On further questioning, he admits having hematuria. Urinalysis shows RBC casts and 400 mL of urine is excreted in 24 hours. What is the most likely cause of hemoptysis and hematuria in this patient?

model_response:
This patient's presentation is most consistent with Goodpasture syndrome, a rare autoimmune disease characterized by pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis. The disease is caused by antibodies directed against the noncollagenous domain of the a3 chain of collagen IV. These antibodies can be detected in the serum of more than 90% of patients with Goodpasture syndrome. Anti-Smith antibodies are seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are seen in patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are seen in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis. Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies are seen in patients with anti-glomerular basement disease.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Expectoration or spitting of blood originating from any part of the RESPIRATORY TRACT, usually from hemorrhage in the lung parenchyma (PULMONARY ALVEOLI) and the BRONCHIAL ARTERIES.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
A chest X-ray finding indicating the presence of a radio-opaque area in the lung. The opacification is caused by fluid or solid material within the airways or lung parenchyma.
Used to describe an individual who is unsure of their sexual orientation.
Presence of blood in the urine.

Examination of urine by chemical, physical, or microscopic means. Routine urinalysis usually includes performing chemical screening tests, determining specific gravity, observing any unusual color or odor, screening for bacteriuria, and examining the sediment microscopically.
Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing HEMOGLOBIN whose function is to transport OXYGEN.
Liquid by-product of excretion produced in the kidneys, temporarily stored in the bladder until discharge through the URETHRA.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Expectoration or spitting of blood originating from any part of the RESPIRATORY TRACT, usually from hemorrhage in the lung parenchyma (PULMONARY ALVEOLI) and the BRONCHIAL ARTERIES.
Presence of blood in the urine.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
